I just looked on CNN and it said:
 
 BREAKING NEWS: President Bush's policy in Iraq "is not working," the Iraq Study Group said in releasing its long-awaited report.
 
 Oh wow, that's is real breaking news indeed. emoticon_rolleyes 
 Well no #### it's not working. Did they actually need a study group to figure that one out?
 The real reason for the ISG of course is to give the Bush Administration a way to change the course without losing any face. And by taking the ISG report to heart, the administration will be seen as reaching across the aisle in a gesture of bipartisanship.
 
 Good move too to have James Baker (Bush family consiglieri) be part of the ISG. It's a good thing for GW that his dad still has the brains and power to get his baby boy out of trouble.

 ROFLMAO.
 
 What makes you think I give a damn about the Democrats. I'm just pointing out how (openly) phony and corrupt American politics has become.
 You can bet your XXX that all those guys in the ISG (Dems and Repubs) got paid well for their "efforts" to enlighten us about the situation and options for Iraq.

Well, Democrats and Republicans are what you have to deal with.
 At least that matter at this time. 
 You must be pretty miserable.

I just looked on CNN and it said:
 
 BREAKING NEWS: President Bush's policy in Iraq "is not working," the Iraq Study Group said in releasing its long-awaited report.
 
 Oh wow, that's is real breaking news indeed. emoticon_rolleyes 
 Well no #### it's not working. Did they actually need a study group to figure that one out?
 The real reason for the ISG of course is to give the Bush Administration a way to change the course without losing any face. And by taking the ISG report to heart, the administration will be seen as reaching across the aisle in a gesture of bipartisanship.
 
 Good move too to have James Baker (Bush family consiglieri) be part of the ISG. It's a good thing for GW that his dad still has the brains and power to get his baby boy out of trouble.

 
 
 But they so clearly aren't going to do what the ISG reccomends, this was pretty much all the news was showing over here last night - the three big reccomendations was to threaten to leave unless the police steps up (which is an awful plan seeing as even on the news they quite readily admit that a lot of the sectarian violence is actually being carried out by them), talk to Iran and Syria and get them involved with promoting stability (but Iran is quite happy as it is and the last time they helped the US they got labeled part of the Axis of evil. Not to mention the slightly bizarre tactic of demanding Iran stops its nuclear program so the US can talk to them about Iran helping them) and finally to push a lot more fiercely for the Israel/Palistine peace process (which isn't going to happen as it would too negatively effect Israeli/US relations).
 
 The solutions were widely regarded as the weakest part of the report, far more important was the statement that a humanitarian catestrophy is inevitable unless some monumental effort is put in to prevent it.

I read a summary of the report. Typical political non-offensive, non-obligatory rehash of known circumstances with known options reiterated. 
 
 A key comment by the White House;
 
 ~White House aides, however, said Bush does not share the Iraq Study Group's uncertainty about the ultimate success of the U.S. mission.
 
 ''The president feels confident (of victory in Iraq) for the following reason ... The president believes in the transformational power of liberty,'' White House spokesman Tony Snow said.~
 
 
 Here's an interesting section of the report regarding US under-reporting of violence in Iraq:
 
 http://www.kansascity.com/mld/kansascity/news/politics/16181637.htm
 
 ~On page 94 of its report, the Iraq Study Group found that there had been "significant under-reporting of the violence in Iraq." The reason, the group said, was because the tracking system was designed in a way that minimized the deaths of Iraqis.
 
 "The standard for recording attacks acts as a filter to keep events out of reports and databases," the report said. "A murder of an Iraqi is not necessarily counted as an attack. If we cannot determine the source of a sectarian attack, that assault does not make it into the database.
 
 A roadside bomb or a rocket or mortar attack that doesn't hurt U.S. personnel doesn't count.~
